unittitle.value: Edward Farbenblum and Orly Lieberman collection of photographs

abstract.value: This collection, assembled and donated by Edward Farbenblum and Orly Lieberman, contains New York Theatre and Hollywood Film portraits and production photos dating from 1924-1993, as well as a small amount of ephemera.

p.value: Available by advance appointment only. To schedule an appointment, contact the Print Room Librarian at printroom@nyhistory.org. Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)

This collection should be cited as Edward Farbenblum and Orly Lieberman Collection of Photographs, PR 378, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.
Gift of Edward Farbenblum and Orly Lieberman, 2013 and 2016.
This series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

subject.value: Theatrical productions -- New York (State) -- New York   -- 1900-2000

dsc.value:
Series I. New York Theatre618521924-1993Scope and Contents

Three photographers and studios are represented in the series: Florence Vandamm, of Vandamm Studio (in operation in New York from 1924 to 1964), has been posited as the "inventor" of the commercial head shot and noted for her use of lighting, costume and movement.

Leo Friedman and Joseph Abeles commenced their publicity photography parternship Friedman-Abeles in 1954 and produced documented the New York theatrical world using their handheld Rolleiflex camera.

Martha Swope, of Swope Associates, was a former dancer who also began her photographic career in the 1950s and, like Friedman-Abeles, shot backstage activities and the rehearsal process for publicity and documentary purposes.

Most productions depicted in the collection are from Broadway, though some national tours, international troupes such as France's Theatre National Populaire, and off-Broadway programming such as the Brooklyn Academy of Music Next Wave Festival appear. The collection documents the original runs of iconic musicals My Fair Lady, A Little Night Music, A Chorus Line, Oklahoma!, 1776, and Cats (the title most substantially represented in the collection), in addition to new plays, revivals, and multiple iterations of productions such as Cat on a Hot Tin Roof and Tennessee Williams's The Night of the Iguana. Notable subjects include theatre stalwarts such as Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt (in Quadrille) and a young Robert De Niro (in Last Stand, with Diane Ladd, and later Cuba and His Teddy Bear).

There are also portraits of Judy Holliday, Helen Hayes, and others, and a small selection of Swope's ballet and dance photography, including the New York City Ballet and its star ballerina Patricia McBride. Additionally, this series contains a small number of Playbill programs, press kit materials, clippings, and ticket stubs.

Playbills and Publicity Materials1969-1990Theatre Productions: Publicity Files - Find Your Way Home62526197451-2Theatre Productions: Publicity Files - Making Movies62527199053-4Theatre Productions: Publicity Files - Seven Days of Mourning62528196955Series II. Hollywood Film618531927-1986Scope and Contents

This series includes publicity and glamour portraits, on-set production shots, and special photography from a variety of studios and photographers such as Clarence Sinclair Bull, George Hurrell, Frank Powolny, and John Egstead. Stars depicted include Katharine Hepburn, Bette Davis, Lana Turner, Clark Gable, Lena Horne, Ava Gardner, Ginger Rogers, Lassie the dog, Eve Arden, and Catherine Deneuve.

This series also includes an Annie Leibovitz photoshoot with Diane Keaton, Sissy Spacek, and Jessica Lange on the set of Crimes of the Heart (1986), and George Hurrell coverage of the red carpet arrivals at the film premiere of The Rose Tattoo (December 2, 1955), held at the Hotel Astor in New York City.
